title: Concatenate JS for Free with Jekyll
content: This one’s a stupid little trick, but I literally use it all the time, and I’m always surprised how novel people find it when I explain it to them. Basically: use Liquid includes in a bundle.js file, and let Jekyll smash all your .js crap together for you.
author: Bryan Schuetz

title: Jousting with Jekyll
content: One responsibility of the support team here at Highrise is to maintain our Extras page.
author: Chris Gallo

title: How I’m Using Jekyll in 2016
content: I first started using Jekyll — a static site generator, back in 2012. In the four years since, it has indirectly introduced me to a host of new tools and ways of building websites. Hell, I wasn’t even using version control when developing this site — so you know a lot has changed.
author: Michael Rose

title: Creating dynamic layouts with Jekyll
content: How we used YAML front-matter to massively change the layout for different posts on our agency’s new website
author: Zander Martineau

title: Building a static blog using Jekyll and Strapi
content: A static website contains Web pages with fixed content. Technically, it is a simple list of HTML files, which displays the same information to every visitor. Unlike dynamic websites, they do not require any back-end programming or database. Publishing a static website is easy: the files are uploaded on a simple Web server or storage provider. The two main advantages of static websites are security and speed: there is no database so it can not be hacked and there is no need to render a page for each request, which makes Web browsing faster.
author: Strapi

title: Why Learn Functional Programming in JavaScript? (Composing Software)
content: Forget whatever you think you know about JavaScript, and approach this material with a beginner’s mind. To help you do that, we’re going to review the JavaScript basics from the ground up, as if you’ve never seen JavaScript before. If you’re a beginner, you’re in luck. Finally something exploring ES6 and functional programming from scratch!
author: Eric Elliott

title: A Quick Introduction to Functional Javascript
content: Functional programming is one of the hottest trends right now and there’s a lot of good arguments about why one might want to utilize it in their code. I’m not going to go into a lot of detail about all of the concepts and ideas of functional programming here, however I will try to provide a demonstrative guide of how to use functional programming in everyday situations involving Javascript.
author: Angelos Chalaris

title: JavaScript: What Are Pure Functions And Why Use Them?
content: The first time I heard the term “Pure Function” I was confused. What was wrong with a regular function? Why does it need to be pure? Why do I even need pure functions?
author: James Jeffery

title: How to Organize React Files Before It’s Messed Up
content: You got to keep your home organized to find things when you’re in need. That’s also correct for programming too. Are you putting your socks into the correct drawer? Let’s find it out.
author: Doğuşcan Namal

title: React render props
content: When I started working in Stored, the Jan Cassio was showing me the code of one of the repositories there, and when I was looking I saw a pattern that looked like a High Order Component, but he told me it was a pattern he had seen a brother talk, and called render prop.
author: Stored E-commerce

title: Mobx React — Best Practices
content: In this article I want to show you common best practices for using React with mobx. I will present them as rules. So whenever you come to a specific problem, try to solve it while sticking to these rules.
author: Daniel Bischoff

title: Setting up a React project from scratch
content: There are lots of react project seeds we can use in place of starting a project from scratch but then they come with a lot of boilerplate hard to make sense for a beginner who is just starting out.
author: Manoj Singh Negi
